description: From Old French contrepois, contrepeser, later assimilated to poise.

entries.meaning: A weight sufficient to balance another, for example in the opposite end of scales; an equal weight.
An effect of equal power or force acting in opposition; a force sufficient to balance another force or influence
The relation of two weights or forces which balance each other; equilibrium

verbs.description: counterpoise (third-person singular simple present counterpoises, present participle counterpoising, simple past and past participle counterpoised)

entries.meaning: To act against with equal weight; to equal in weight; to balance the weight of; to counterbalance.
To act against with equal power; to balance.
examples: So many freeholders of English  [â€¦] will be able to beard, and to counterpoise the rest.
